items.title: Aboriginal artist Bobbi Lockyer in tears as Australia Post loses $4k painting
items.description: Indigenous artist Bobbi Lockyer has been left frustrated after she sent a $4,000 custom artwork of the Pilbara to a buyer in Queensland, only for an empty cardboard sleeve to be delivered.

items.title: Why does Trump want Greenland and why is it so important?
items.description: Donald Trump's continued interest in Greenland is part of his "America First" agenda to dominate the Western Hemisphere and contain China's interests in the region.

items.title: Ukraine, US discuss territorial ideas at Paris peace talks

featured_image.name: Ukraine allies agree to security guarantees in peace plan - NPR

items.description:
US and Ukrainian officials discussed "some ideas" to resolve territorial disputes in peace talks held in Paris on Tuesday, with President Volodymyr Zelenskiy identifying the issue as the biggest remaining obstacle to ending Russia's war against Ukraine.

"The biggest issue that needs to be worked on is the territorial issue. We discussed some ideas that might help," Zelenskiy said following a meeting with more than 30 allies in the French capital[1][2]. White House special envoy Steve Witkoff confirmed that land options were discussed during the talks and that consultations would continue[1].

The territorial question centers on the eastern Donetsk region, where Russia is demanding Ukraine surrender remaining areas under its control. Ukraine previously said the US proposed creating a "free economic zone" if Kyiv withdraws from parts of Donetsk still held by Ukrainian forces[1][3]. The proposal would establish a demilitarized area, though uncertainty remains over who would govern the territory[3]

items.title: Nvidia, AMD, Intel unveil competing AI chips at CES

featured_image.name: Jensen Huang CES keynote ignites analyst optimism on ... - CNBC

items.description:
The world's leading chipmakers showcased next-generation processors and AI platforms at CES 2026 this week, marking an industry-wide shift toward "physical AI" systems designed to power robots, autonomous vehicles, and smart factories rather than just data centers[1][2][3][4][5].

Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang opened CES on Monday with the surprise announcement that the company's Vera Rubin computing platform is already in full production, months ahead of its previously projected late-2026 timeline[3][6][7]. The six-chip system, which includes the Rubin GPU and new Vera CPU, delivers up to five times more AI training power than the current Blackwell architecture while reducing inference token costs by roughly one-tenth, according to Nvidia[3][6][8].

Huang also unveiled Alpamayo, an open-source family of AI models designed specifically for autonomous vehicles[9][10]. The system uses chain-of-thought reasoning to help self-driving cars navigate complex scenarios and explain their decisions. Mercedes-Benz plans to integrate Alpamayo into its upcoming CLA model, set to arrive at U.S. dealerships in the first quarter of 2026[11]

items.title: Iran raids hospitals to detain injured protesters

featured_image.name: Iran protests continue with at least 29 killed, 1,200 detained, activists ...

items.description:
Iran's government announced a $7 monthly stipend for citizens as nationwide protests entered their tenth day, with at least 36 people killed and security forces raiding hospitals to detain injured demonstrators—marking the most severe unrest since the 2022 Mahsa Amini uprising.

The protests, which began December 28 in Tehran's Grand Bazaar, have spread to 27 of Iran's 31 provinces as the country's currency collapsed to a record low of 1.47 million rials to the dollar and inflation reached 42% in December[1][2]. Government spokesperson Fatemeh Mohajerani announced Monday that approximately 80 million Iranians would receive monthly payments of 10 million rials—about $7—starting January 10, redirecting $10 billion previously allocated for import subsidies[3]

items.title: 'It feels wrong': Final Bondi terror attack funeral held in Sydney
items.description: A retired detective has been remembered as an "incredibly moral and honest man" at a funeral service three weeks after he was killed in the Bondi terror attack.

items.title: The US may have Nicolás Maduro but 'the prince' remains in Caracas
items.description: Nicolás Maduro Guerra rose through the ranks of his father's government and remains in Caracas. It's uncertain for how long.

items.title: Floods kill dozens worldwide as scientists link disasters to climate change, deforestation

featured_image.name: California Flooding Breaks Multiple Records - Newsweek

items.description:
Devastating floods continued to strike across multiple continents this week, killing dozens and displacing thousands as scientists warn that climate change and widespread deforestation are amplifying extreme weather disasters worldwide.

California faced record flooding over the weekend, with rare "king tides" combining with heavy rainfall to inundate coastal areas from Santa Barbara to San Francisco[1][2][3]. One person died in Santa Barbara County after being swept into a creek, while the Santa Barbara Airport closed operations due to floodwaters covering runways[1][2]. San Francisco recorded its highest tide since 1998, with water levels reaching 2.56 feet above normal[3][4].

In Queensland, Australia, catastrophic flooding killed at least one person and left more than 19,000 livestock dead or missing as of Monday[5][6]. The Australian government announced a $38 million disaster recovery package for affected communities[5][7]. Meanwhile, flash floods in Indonesia's North Sulawesi province killed at least 14 people on Monday, with six others still missing[8]

items.title: 'Very pleasant surprise': inflation cools but remains above RBA target
items.description: Inflation cooled in November, with the consumer price index rising 3.4 per cent over the year, down from 3.8 per cent a month earlier. Some economists continue to forecast a February rate hike, however.

items.title: UK, France pledge troops to Ukraine after ceasefire

featured_image.name: France and UK commit to deploying troops to Ukraine if ceasefire is agreed with Russia

items.description:
The United Kingdom and France signed a historic declaration on Tuesday committing to deploy military forces to Ukraine in the event of a peace deal with Russia, marking the most concrete security guarantee yet offered to Kyiv by Western allies.

British Prime Minister Keir Starmer and French President Emmanuel Macron announced at a Coalition of the Willing summit in Paris that their countries would establish military hubs across Ukraine and build protected facilities for weapons and equipment to support Ukrainian defense operations[1][2][3][4]. The agreement, signed alongside Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, was backed by representatives from 35 countries, including US envoys Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner[1][4][5].

"Following a ceasefire, the UK and France will establish military hubs across Ukraine and build protected facilities for weapons and military equipment to support Ukraine's defensive needs," Starmer said at a joint press conference[1][2]. The declaration establishes the legal framework for British, French, and partner forces to operate on Ukrainian territory, securing airspace and waters while rebuilding Ukraine's military

items.title: How an encounter with an AI hallucination raised an ethical dilemma
items.description: When a journalist emails a company with questions looking for answers, the least they expect is a real person to feed them the spin, half-truths or outright lies. Not a machine.

items.title: Nvidia, AMD, Intel unveil AI chip platforms at CES
items.description:
The world's leading semiconductor companies unveiled their latest artificial intelligence innovations at CES 2026 in Las Vegas this week, with Nvidia, AMD, and Intel all announcing new chip platforms designed to power the next generation of AI applications[1][2][3].

Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang kicked off the show Monday with a keynote focused on "physical AI"—artificial intelligence models trained in virtual environments that can control real-world machines[1][2]. Huang announced the Vera Rubin platform, now in full production, which features six separate chips and can deliver five times the AI computing performance of previous generations[4][2]. The company also introduced Cosmos, a foundational model for simulating physical environments, and Alpamayo, an AI model specifically designed for autonomous vehicles that will be integrated into the new Mercedes-Benz CLA later this year[2]

items.title: Live: Jacob Bethell scores first Test century as England takes lead at SCG
items.description: England is suddenly in the driver's seat of the final Ashes Test on the back of 22-year-old Jacob Bethell's maiden first-class century in just his sixth Test match. Follow live.

items.title: Live: Emergency warnings for fires in Victoria as heatwave sweeps across southern Australia
items.description: Large areas of Australia, from Western Australia's north-west to Tasmania's north-east, have been issued with severe to extreme heatwave warnings from Wednesday to Saturday. Follow our live blog.

items.title: Interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS shows no alien signals

featured_image.name: Rapid brightening of interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS as it nears ...

items.description:
Astronomers scanning the rare interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS for signs of extraterrestrial technology have found nothing but natural astrophysical processes at work, according to findings released this week by the Breakthrough Listen project[1][2]. The search, which included the most sensitive radio observations ever conducted on an interstellar object, ruled out any continuous radio transmitters stronger than approximately 0.1 watts at the comet's location[1][3][4].

The 100-meter Green Bank Telescope observed 3I/ATLAS on December 18, 2025, one day before its closest approach to Earth[5][1][6]. Initial scans flagged roughly 470,000 candidate signals, but all were eventually traced to human-made radio interference[2][4]. "In the end, there were no surprises," lead researcher Benjamin Jacobson-Bell told Space.com[5]. Similar searches using the Allen Telescope Array, MeerKAT in South Africa, and other facilities worldwide reached the same conclusion[1][6]

items.title: Robot vacuums climb stairs as CES showcases physical AI

featured_image.name: Roborock's Rover walks, jumps, and vacuums your stairs - The Verge

items.description:
The world's largest technology showcase opened its doors in Las Vegas on Monday with a decisive pivot toward "physical AI"—systems that move, navigate, and operate in real-world environments rather than just processing data on screens. Chipmakers Nvidia, AMD, and Intel unveiled next-generation processors designed to power this shift, while robot manufacturers demonstrated machines that can finally tackle one of home automation's last frontiers: climbing stairs.

Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang kicked off the show by announcing the Vera Rubin platform, a next-generation AI superchip architecture now in full production that the company claims offers more than triple the speed of its current Blackwell chips[1][2]. The platform, named after astronomer Vera Rubin, combines six chips into what Nvidia calls "one AI supercomputer," with products expected to roll out from partners in the second half of 2026[2][3].

"The moment for physical AI has arrived—when machines start to comprehend, reason, and operate in the real world," Huang said during his keynote[4]. He also unveiled Alpamayo, an AI model for autonomous vehicles that uses vision-language-action models to handle unfamiliar driving scenarios[2][5]. Mercedes-Benz CEO Ola Källenius reported testing the Nvidia-powered system on public roads, driving for more than an hour through heavy traffic, with the vehicles expected to launch in the first quarter of 2026[2].

AMD CEO Lisa Su showcased the company's Ryzen AI 400 series processors for PCs, claiming 1.3 times faster multitasking and 1.7 times quicker content creation compared to competitors[6][7]. The company also detailed its forthcoming MI500 series data center GPUs, asserting they will deliver up to a 1,000-fold enhancement in AI performance compared to the MI300X GPUs[7]. Intel announced its Panther Lake processors, branded as Core Ultra Series 3, featuring up to 180 platform TOPS (trillions of operations per second) for AI acceleration and claiming more than 50% faster CPU and graphics performance versus the previous generation[8]

items.title: Europa may lack energy to support life, study says

featured_image.name: Europa: A guide to Jupiter's icy moon | Space

items.description:
A new study published this week suggests that Jupiter's moon Europa—long considered one of the most promising places to search for extraterrestrial life—may lack the underwater geological activity necessary to sustain organisms in its vast subsurface ocean[1][2][3][4].

Researchers led by Paul Byrne, an associate professor of Earth, environmental, and planetary sciences at Washington University in St. Louis, calculated that Europa's seafloor is likely too quiet to support life today[2][3][5]. The study, published January 5 in Nature Communications, concludes that the moon probably lacks tectonic motion, warm hydrothermal vents, or other underwater geologic activity that would provide energy for potential life forms[1][2]

items.title: Live: ASX adds to gains as inflation slows more than expected
items.description: The CPI rose 3.4 per cent in the 12 months to November 2025, according to the latest ABS data — down from 3.8 per cent in October and below economists' expectations. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

items.title: Colombia's Petro vows armed resistance after Trump threats

featured_image.name: U.S. slaps sanctions on Colombia President Petro over drug ... - NPR

items.description:
Colombian President Gustavo Petro issued a stark warning to the United States on Monday, declaring he would take up arms to defend his nation's sovereignty after President Donald Trump accused him of cocaine trafficking and threatened military intervention[1][2][3][4][5].

"I swore not to touch a weapon again since the 1989 Peace Pact, but for the Homeland I will take up arms again," Petro wrote on X, referring to his past as a member of the M-19 urban guerrilla group[2][5]. The former rebel fighter, who became Colombia's first leftist president in 2022, warned that any attempt to detain him would "unleash the popular jaguar" of the Colombian people[6][2][5].

items.title: US discussing possible military options in pursuit of acquiring Greenland
items.description: The US president and his officials are continuing to push for an American takeover of the Danish territory in the wake of their successful Venezuela operation, saying the island is needed for national security.

items.title: Feds Launch Massive Taxpayer Fraud Probe in Minnesota After Viral Video
items.description: Federal agencies including DHS, FBI, and ICE investigate $110 million in suspected fraud at Minnesota child care centers following a viral YouTube video[3].
